user_query: Can you draft a partner-ready memo section on the controlling Rule 12(b)(6) pleading standard for a § 1983 supervisory-liability claim against a county sheriff in the Central District of California? Plaintiff’s opposition leans hard on Conley/Swierkiewicz/Erickson for “notice pleading,” and also cites Starr v. Baca. I want the best authority-hierarchy way to frame why some of those cases don’t control (or do) and what standard the judge should actually apply.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court for the Central District of California (Ninth Circuit).', 'Claim at issue: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 claim against the county sheriff in his individual capacity for unconstitutional conditions of confinement / failure to protect, framed as deliberate indifference (not an equal-protection or purposeful discrimination claim).', 'Pleadings posture: defendant sheriff is moving to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6).', 'Complaint allegations against the sheriff: largely supervisory—plaintiff pleads the sheriff received DOJ findings letters and multiple internal/external reports about prior inmate violence and deputy misconduct, but does not allege the sheriff was present at the incident or personally ordered the specific deputy actions at issue.', 'Plaintiff argues the complaint survives because under Conley and Swierkiewicz, dismissal is improper unless there is “no set of facts” supporting relief; plaintiff cites Erickson to argue specific facts are not necessary; and plaintiff cites Starr v. Baca to argue that knowledge/acquiescence plus inaction can establish supervisory liability for deliberate indifference at the pleading stage.', 'Defense position: Conley’s “no set of facts” language is not the governing standard after Twombly/Iqbal; the court must apply plausibility and disregard conclusory allegations; but in the Ninth Circuit the court must also follow Starr on how supervisory deliberate-indifference claims can be pleaded post-Iqbal.', 'You may assume there is no conflicting state-law pleading rule and no heightened pleading statute (e.g., PSLRA) applicable. The only pleading authorities available are those in this packet.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001.P002.B06', 'DOC001.P019.B02'], ['DOC002.P002.B06', 'DOC002.P003.B03', 'DOC002.P017.B06'], ['DOC003.P008.B05', 'DOC003.P007.B03', 'DOC003.P007.B04']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade down if the memo states or implies that a cited case stands for a proposition that is not actually supported by the quoted or cited block. This is especially important here because several packet cases discuss pleading standards at a high level and the temptation is to paraphrase beyond what the text says. The memo must not fabricate procedural posture (e.g., calling something a Ninth Circuit rule if it is a Supreme Court holding) or invent “overruled/abrogated” signals not shown in the packet. If the memo claims that a decision “overruled” another, it must be anchored in packet language reflecting that displacement (for example, Twombly’s explicit treatment of Conley’s ‘no set of facts’ language). If the memo relies on any “standard” (like “no set of facts” or “plausibility”), the grader should check that the cited block actually articulates that standard. Citations that are merely name-drops without supporting text should be treated as unsupported for the proposition asserted.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not attribute to Conley, Swierkiewicz, or Erickson a post-Twombly/Iqbal ‘plausibility’ rule unless the cited block says so.', 'Do not cite Starr v. Baca for a proposition about Supreme Court holdings; Starr is Ninth Circuit authority and must be described as such.', 'Do not claim Conley is still controlling in federal court after Twombly without citing Twombly’s express rejection language from the packet.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'Fail for precedence if the memo treats Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation as the governing Rule 12(b)(6) standard in a federal district court today, or if it uses Swierkiewicz/Erickson to revive Conley’s test as controlling despite later Supreme Court authority. That mistake is legally wrong in this packet because Twombly explicitly retires/repudiates Conley’s “no set of facts” language and replaces it with a plausibility-based understanding of Rule 8, and Iqbal reaffirms and operationalizes Twombly’s approach (including the rule that conclusory allegations are not assumed true). The correct authority handling must (i) identify Twombly and Iqbal as controlling Supreme Court pleading-standard decisions for Rule 8/Rule 12(b)(6), (ii) explain that older formulations like Conley’s “no set of facts” cannot be treated as binding after Twombly’s explicit treatment, and (iii) then correctly place Starr v. Baca in the hierarchy as binding Ninth Circuit authority for how supervisory liability/deliberate indifference pleading is applied in Ninth Circuit courts so long as it is consistent with the Supreme Court’s Twombly/Iqbal framework. A response may still cite Swierkiewicz or Erickson, but it must reconcile them with (and not elevate them over) Twombly/Iqbal, and it must not claim those cases set the operative dismissal test if the packet shows otherwise. The memo should expressly frame the hierarchy (Supreme Court over circuit; later-in-time Supreme Court treatment displacing older Supreme Court gloss) when resolving the apparent conflict.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not apply Conley’s “no set of facts” test as current law after Twombly’s explicit retirement of that language.', 'Do not treat Ninth Circuit reasoning as if it can override or dilute Supreme Court Rule 8 interpretations.', 'Do not cite older “notice pleading” language to negate Iqbal’s instruction that courts disregard conclusory allegations at step one.', 'Do not ignore that the forum is a Ninth Circuit district court, where Starr v. Baca is binding circuit authority on deliberate-indifference supervisory pleading if consistent with Supreme Court law.']}

user_query: Draft a partner-ready memo section arguing the district court abused its discretion by dismissing with prejudice and denying leave to amend. I need the governing Supreme Court standard from Foman v. Davis (with the exact factor list and a short quote) and the Ninth Circuit gloss from Eminence Capital (again with a key quote). Please include pinpoint citations and explain how “futility” is evaluated at the pleading stage under Twombly/Iqbal.
scenario_facts: ['We represent plaintiffs in a federal civil rights case in the Ninth Circuit; the district court granted a Rule 12(b)(6) motion and entered dismissal with prejudice.', 'The dismissal order says amendment would be futile because the complaint allegedly fails to plead enough facts to make the theory plausible under Twombly/Iqbal.', 'Partner wants to cite the classic leave-to-amend authorities (Foman and Eminence Capital) and use them to argue the court should have granted at least one more amendment opportunity.', 'We have only the packet materials (Twombly, Iqbal, Starr v. Baca, Eclectic Properties, Conley, Swierkiewicz, Erickson, and Johnson v. City of Shelby) available for support in this assignment.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC008.P003.B02']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This item is designed to catch invented or unsupported legal authority and citations. The packet does not include Foman v. Davis or Eminence Capital, so any answer that supplies a reporter citation, pinpoint, or quotation for those cases should be treated as fabricated and must fail. It is also a failure if the answer attributes a leave-to-amend “factor list” or any verbatim language to Foman or Eminence without packet support, even if the statements sound legally familiar. Likewise, do not reward “made-up” Ninth Circuit case names, dates, docket numbers, or parentheticals that are not in the packet. A passing answer can still be helpful, but it must clearly say the packet does not contain Foman/Eminence and therefore cannot provide exact quotes or pin cites, and it should pivot to the limited amendment-related material that actually appears in the packet (e.g., Rule 15(a)(2) language discussed in Johnson). Credit should be given for explicit, transparent limitations and for refusing to invent citations while accurately using any relevant packet text that exists.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept any invented reporter citations or pinpoints for Foman v. Davis or Eminence Capital; those cases are absent from this packet.', 'Do not accept any purported verbatim quotations from Foman or Eminence; quoting missing cases is necessarily fabricated here.', 'If the answer cites additional authorities not found in the packet (treatises, circuit cases, district cases) with precise cites, treat that as a likely hallucination unless the packet contains them.', 'It is acceptable—and should be rewarded—for the answer to state it cannot provide the requested authorities from the packet and to rely instead on the packet’s Rule 15(a)(2) reference and pleading-standard cases.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query:
Need a partner-ready memo on a Rule 12(b)(6) motion in a C.D. Cal. § 1983 jail-conditions case. Can we get the individual-capacity supervisory-liability claim against the Sheriff dismissed by leaning on Iqbal’s language rejecting “supervisory liability,” or does Ninth Circuit law prevent that? Facts below.

Plaintiff (pretrial detainee) alleges deputies opened his cell door to let other inmates assault him; he was later kicked and called racial slurs by a deputy while other deputies stood by. He sues the Sheriff individually, alleging the Sheriff knew of a long-standing pattern of inmate-on-inmate violence and deputy misconduct through DOJ correspondence, internal reports, prior high-profile incidents, and payouts, but failed to fix classification/supervision and discipline problems. The complaint doesn’t allege the Sheriff was present or personally ordered the assault. We represent the Sheriff.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: United States District Court for the Central District of California; any appeal would go to the Ninth Circuit.', 'Claims: 42 U.S.C. § 1983; unconstitutional conditions of confinement / failure-to-protect theory (deliberate indifference). Plaintiff is a pretrial detainee but pleads Eighth/Fourteenth Amendment deliberate indifference style allegations.', 'Pleading posture: Rule 12(b)(6) motion; complaint includes generalized allegations that the Sheriff received notice of systemic jail violence and deputy misconduct through DOJ communications and internal monitoring, plus references to prior incidents and settlements, but lacks allegations that the Sheriff personally participated in this plaintiff’s incident.', 'Defense theme partner wants assessed: whether Ashcroft v. Iqbal can be used to argue that “supervisory liability” is categorically unavailable and therefore the Sheriff must be dismissed, versus whether controlling Ninth Circuit authority preserves supervisory liability (at least for deliberate-indifference conditions claims).', 'Secondary issue that may tempt sloppy authority handling: plaintiff quotes older ‘no set of facts’/notice-pleading language and argues Conley/Swierkiewicz show dismissal is disfavored at the pleading stage.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC003.P008.B05', 'DOC003.P007.B03', 'DOC003.P007.B04'], ['DOC002.P015.B05', 'DOC002.P016.B04', 'DOC002.P017.B03'], ['DOC001.P002.B05', 'DOC001.P002.B06', 'DOC001.P019.B02']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity strictly. The memo must not attribute to any packet document a holding it does not contain (e.g., claiming the Supreme Court “overruled” Starr v. Baca, or that Starr was a Supreme Court case, or that the Ninth Circuit adopted Conley’s ‘no set of facts’ standard after Twombly). If the memo states a rule, it needs to be anchored in the cited block’s actual text; do not give credit where the citation is merely name-dropping a case without support in the cited passage. Treat any assertion about another circuit’s law, a later abrogation, or a statute/rule amendment as fabricated unless it is expressly supported by a packet citation. If the memo relies on facts (e.g., what Iqbal held, what Twombly did to Conley, or what Starr held about supervisory liability), the cited block must actually say that. If a memo gives a procedural recommendation (e.g., file a Rule 12(e) motion) as if mandated by authority, that also needs packet support or should be framed as strategic advice rather than a legal requirement.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not claim Starr v. Baca was decided by the Supreme Court; it is a Ninth Circuit decision.', 'Do not assert Conley’s “no set of facts” standard remains governing after Twombly without reconciling Twombly’s retirement of that language.', 'Do not invent qualified-immunity or Monell rules not stated in the provided excerpts, especially when advising dismissal grounds.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item tests whether the memo correctly handles binding authority in the Central District of California. A response fails for precedence if it treats Iqbal’s broad language as categorically foreclosing supervisory liability in this deliberate-indifference jail-conditions case and therefore recommends dismissal without engaging the Ninth Circuit’s controlling interpretation in Starr v. Baca. That mistake is legally wrong for this forum because, within the Ninth Circuit, Starr is binding circuit precedent on how Iqbal applies (and does not apply) to deliberate-indifference supervisory-liability claims; district courts must follow Starr unless and until it is displaced by higher authority. To pass, the memo must (i) recognize the hierarchy (Supreme Court + Ninth Circuit binding; older Supreme Court dicta/standards can be displaced by later Supreme Court decisions), (ii) explain that Starr holds Iqbal did not eliminate supervisory liability for conditions-of-confinement claims where the underlying constitutional standard is deliberate indifference, and (iii) separately apply Twombly/Iqbal plausibility pleading (including the rejection of Conley’s “no set of facts” gloss) to evaluate whether the complaint’s allegations against the Sheriff are sufficiently factual and nonconclusory. It is acceptable to argue dismissal on plausibility/causation grounds, but not on the incorrect premise that supervisory liability is unavailable as a matter of law in this circuit and context.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat Supreme Court discussion in Iqbal as automatically dispositive if controlling Ninth Circuit precedent interprets its scope for deliberate-indifference claims.', 'Do not ignore Starr v. Baca when the forum is within the Ninth Circuit and the claim is supervisory liability for deliberate indifference.', 'Do not rely on Conley’s “no set of facts” language as governing after Twombly’s instruction that the phrase is “best forgotten.”', 'Do not equate persuasive or background commentary about pleading with binding holdings; identify what actually controls the issue presented.']}

user_query:
Can you draft a partner-ready memo on whether we should move to dismiss a federal complaint that alleges Fourteenth Amendment due process violations against a city but never cites 42 U.S.C. § 1983? Please address (i) whether failure to plead § 1983 is a viable Rule 12(b)(6) ground and (ii) separately whether the complaint’s factual allegations are enough under current pleading law.

Facts: Former city employees allege they were fired for whistleblowing. The complaint says the city violated due process by firing them “without notice or a hearing,” but it’s light on specifics (no details on what process was requested/denied, who made the decision, or what property interest they had). Case is in federal district court in California.
scenario_facts: ['Forum and posture: U.S. District Court in California; defendant city is considering a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss at the pleading stage.', 'Parties/claims: Plaintiffs sue the city only (no individual officers named) for alleged Fourteenth Amendment due process violations seeking damages; the complaint does not cite 42 U.S.C. § 1983 or use the phrase “Section 1983.”', 'Key pleading defects asserted by defendant: (a) omission of § 1983 as the cause of action vehicle; (b) the complaint’s factual allegations are largely conclusory (e.g., “no notice or hearing”) and do not explain what procedures were due, requested, or denied, or identify other concrete facts supporting entitlement to relief.', 'Research constraint for this exercise: analysis should be supportable from the packet authorities about federal pleading standards and § 1983 pleading.', 'Hierarchy issue embedded in the packet: older Supreme Court language suggesting the Conley ‘no set of facts’ dismissal standard versus later Supreme Court decisions adopting/clarifying the plausibility standard, and a separate Supreme Court decision rejecting dismissal based only on failure to invoke § 1983.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC008.P001.B04', 'DOC008.P002.B06', 'DOC008.P003.B02'], ['DOC001.P019.B02', 'DOC001.P002.B06', 'DOC001.P002.B05'], ['DOC002.P003.B03', 'DOC002.P017.B03', 'DOC002.P018.B03']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity by checking whether the cited blocks actually support the proposition stated in the memo. The memo may not attribute holdings or standards to a case unless that point is contained in the cited excerpt. If the memo claims, for example, that a particular pleading test is controlling, it must cite the packet language that states or applies that test; general references to “notice pleading” without tying it to the quoted authority should be treated as unsupported. Do not give credit for citations that are merely nearby in topic but do not contain the claimed rule (e.g., citing a syllabus block that does not say what the memo asserts). If the memo mentions jurisdiction-specific rules, sanctions standards, Monell elements, or qualified immunity consequences, those must be supported by packet text; otherwise treat them as fabricated. If a memo cites any non-packet case or adds details about a case’s later history not contained in the packet, treat that as uncited and unreliable for grading. The key is whether the authority cited, as excerpted here, really says what the memo uses it for.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit citations that discuss Rule 8 generally but do not contain the specific rule the memo asserts.', 'Do not credit a citation to Conley or Swierkiewicz for the modern plausibility standard; that standard must be supported by Twombly/Iqbal excerpts.', 'If the memo asserts Johnson v. City of Shelby requires dismissal or requires pleading § 1983, that is the opposite of the excerpt and should be marked as unsupported.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is a precedence/hierarchy test about which authorities control and how later, higher authority changes or limits earlier formulations. A response fails if it treats Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation as the governing federal Rule 12(b)(6) standard without acknowledging that Twombly retired/rejected that language and replaced it with a plausibility framework. A response also fails if it recommends dismissal solely because the complaint did not expressly invoke § 1983, or if it treats any lower-court approach requiring an explicit § 1983 citation as controlling, because Johnson v. City of Shelby is Supreme Court authority holding Rule 8 does not permit dismissal for imperfect statement of the legal theory and specifically rejects requiring an express § 1983 invocation. Correct authority handling must (1) identify Johnson as controlling on the “failure to cite § 1983” ground (at most allowing amendment), and (2) separately apply Twombly/Iqbal’s plausibility approach to the complaint’s factual sufficiency (distinguishing legal-theory defects from factual-deficiency analysis). The memo may argue dismissal is still appropriate on factual-pleading grounds, but only if it uses the controlling plausibility standard and does not resurrect Conley as controlling law.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat Conley’s “no set of facts” language as current controlling law after Twombly’s explicit retirement of that phrase.', 'Do not recommend dismissal purely for failing to cite § 1983; Johnson is controlling Supreme Court authority rejecting that basis for threshold dismissal.', 'Do not treat a circuit court’s gloss as overruling or displacing a Supreme Court pleading holding; Supreme Court decisions control.', 'Do not conflate Johnson’s point (legal theory citation not required) with the separate Twombly/Iqbal requirement that factual allegations must be plausible.']}

user_query:
Need a partner-ready memo section for a Rule 12(b)(6) motion we’re drafting in the Central District of California. Plaintiff (a former LA County Jail inmate) is suing the Sheriff in his individual capacity under § 1983 for unconstitutional conditions / failure to protect (deliberate indifference), based on a single assault by other inmates. Plaintiff’s opposition leans heavily on Conley/Swierkiewicz notice pleading (“no set of facts”) and also argues Iqbal didn’t change pleading outside antitrust. Separately, they say supervisory liability survives because the Sheriff supposedly knew of prior incidents.

Can you analyze the governing pleading standard and the current state of supervisory liability in the Ninth Circuit for an Eighth/Fourteenth deliberate-indifference claim, and how we should frame our dismissal arguments?
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court, Central District of California (Ninth Circuit).', 'Claims: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 damages claim against the Sheriff in his individual capacity for unconstitutional jail conditions / failure to protect (deliberate indifference under the Eighth Amendment as incorporated through the Fourteenth).', 'Core incident alleged: Plaintiff says deputies opened his cell door and allowed other inmates to enter and assault him; he alleges serious injuries. Plaintiff does not allege the Sheriff was present or personally participated in the assault.', 'Pleading posture: Defendant is preparing a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss the individual-capacity supervisory-liability claim against the Sheriff.', 'Plaintiff’s opposition briefing cites Conley v. Gibson for the proposition that a complaint survives unless it appears beyond doubt plaintiff can prove “no set of facts,” and cites Swierkiewicz to argue federal pleading is still purely notice-based.', 'Plaintiff also argues Twombly should be limited to antitrust and that Iqbal should be confined to discrimination/qualified-immunity cases.', 'Plaintiff attempts to plead the Sheriff’s liability by listing alleged prior DOJ findings letters/reports, past inmate-on-inmate violence incidents, and generalized assertions that the Sheriff ‘knew or should have known’ about risks and failed to correct them.', 'Defense theme: Plaintiff is trying to impose respondeat superior-like liability on the Sheriff and has not plausibly pleaded a causal connection between any specific Sheriff action/inaction and plaintiff’s specific assault.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P017.B03', 'DOC002.P017.B04', 'DOC001.P001.B06'], ['DOC001.P002.B05', 'DOC001.P002.B06', 'DOC001.P019.B02'], ['DOC003.P007.B03', 'DOC003.P007.B04', 'DOC003.P008.B05']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'The memo must accurately describe what the cited authorities actually say, and must not attribute to a case a rule it does not contain. If the response claims that Conley remains the governing Rule 12(b)(6) test, or that Twombly/Iqbal merely apply to antitrust or discrimination, it must be supported by the packet; otherwise treat it as a fabricated or unsupported legal proposition. The same is true for statements about whether supervisory liability is “abolished” or “unchanged”: the memo must ground those status assertions in the packet’s text. A citation that is real but does not support the specific proposition stated (e.g., citing Iqbal for a proposition about negligence pleading) should be graded as a citation integrity problem. If the memo quotes or paraphrases a holding, it must match the holding’s scope and context as reflected in the packet. Any extra-jurisdictional or post-packet developments (e.g., later Ninth Circuit cases) count as unsupported and should be flagged. When in doubt, graders should check whether the cited block actually contains the claimed rule in close paraphrase.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not cite Conley or Swierkiewicz as if they announce the current controlling dismissal standard after Twombly.', 'Do not claim Iqbal is limited to antitrust or qualified-immunity contexts without packet support.', 'Do not attribute to Starr v. Baca a Supreme Court holding; it is a Ninth Circuit decision interpreting Iqbal.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'Fail for precedence if the memo treats Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation as the operative Rule 12(b)(6) standard in federal court, or relies on Swierkiewicz/Erickson to override Twombly and Iqbal’s plausibility framework without acknowledging Twombly’s retirement of Conley’s quoted language. That hierarchy mistake is legally wrong because Twombly (Supreme Court, later in time) expressly retires the Conley phrasing and articulates the plausibility requirement, and Iqbal reaffirms and applies that Rule 8 pleading approach outside antitrust. Also fail if the memo tells the partner that Iqbal categorically eliminated supervisory liability for all § 1983 claims in the Ninth Circuit and recommends dismissal on that basis while ignoring Ninth Circuit binding authority that interprets Iqbal in the deliberate-indifference conditions-of-confinement context. Correct authority handling must: (i) identify Twombly/Iqbal as controlling on Rule 8/12(b)(6) plausibility and note Conley’s status as superseded/retired on that point; and (ii) treat Starr v. Baca as binding Ninth Circuit law on supervisory liability for deliberate indifference claims (as distinguished from Iqbal’s purposeful-discrimination context), even if the memo argues the plaintiff still fails to plead sufficient facts under that standard.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not use Conley’s “no set of facts” phrase as the governing dismissal test after Twombly.', 'Do not claim Twombly is confined to antitrust; Iqbal addresses and rejects that limitation.', 'Do not treat Supreme Court dicta, dissents, or lower-court reasoning as overriding controlling holdings.', 'Do not argue supervisory liability is universally abolished based solely on Iqbal when Ninth Circuit precedent in this packet addresses supervisory liability for deliberate indifference.']}

user_query: Need a partner-ready memo section for a Rule 12(b)(6) motion in a Ninth Circuit §1983 case: can we knock out an individual-capacity supervisory-liability claim against the County Sheriff by arguing Iqbal forecloses liability based on “knowledge and acquiescence”? Facts below.
scenario_facts: ['We represent the County Sheriff, sued in his individual capacity under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.', 'Plaintiff is a pretrial detainee who alleges he was stabbed by other inmates after deputies allegedly left multiple cell doors unlocked and ignored his calls for help. He pleads a conditions-of-confinement / failure-to-protect theory using “deliberate indifference” language under the Eighth/Fourteenth Amendments.', 'The complaint does not allege the Sheriff was present during the assault, personally spoke to any deputy involved, or personally made the day-to-day housing/monitoring decisions at issue.', 'To plead supervisor liability, the complaint lists: (i) a DOJ findings letter from years earlier criticizing inmate-on-inmate violence and deputy misconduct; (ii) periodic reports/briefings allegedly received by the Sheriff about injuries and deaths in the jail; and (iii) several prior high-profile inmate assaults/killings. The pleading alleges the Sheriff had notice of these systemic problems and failed to fix staffing, training, or supervision.', 'In a separate count, plaintiff also pleads an Equal Protection / discriminatory-classification claim, alleging deputies were placing Black detainees in units with known gang hostility. As to the Sheriff, the complaint alleges he “knew of and condoned” these discriminatory placement practices but does not allege facts showing he adopted the classification practice for the purpose of discriminating.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC003.P008.B05', 'DOC003.P007.B03'], ['DOC002.P016.B02', 'DOC002.P016.B04', 'DOC002.P015.B05']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'A response should be graded down if it attributes rules or holdings to any authority not in the packet or if it supplies case citations not present in the packet. The memo must not quote, paraphrase, or rely on supposed Ninth Circuit or Supreme Court language that cannot be found in the cited blocks. If the memo states a rule (e.g., what Iqbal “held” about supervisory liability, or what Starr “permits”), it needs a supporting citation token from the packet that actually contains that proposition. If a memo cites the right case but for a proposition that is not in the cited passage (for example, citing Starr for a broad, all-claims rule), treat that as a citation integrity problem as well as a substantive error. Do not give credit for legal-sounding assertions about pleading standards, supervisory liability, or intent requirements unless the packet text supports them. If the memo introduces standards like “Monell policy/custom elements,” “qualified immunity sequencing,” or “plausibility equals probability,” those must be supported by packet text or flagged as unsupported.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit citations to Iqbal or Starr for propositions that appear only in dicta or in a dissent not cited.', 'Do not accept invented Ninth Circuit multi-part tests for supervisory liability unless the cited packet block states the test.', 'Be wary of generic pleading-standard summaries that smuggle in non-packet authorities or standards.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo treats Starr v. Baca as establishing a general rule that supervisory liability based on “knowledge and acquiescence” is sufficient in any §1983 (or Bivens) case, regardless of the constitutional claim’s required state of mind. That is legally wrong under the packet because Starr frames its reading of Iqbal as claim-specific: it distinguishes purposeful discrimination claims (requiring discriminatory purpose) from conditions-of-confinement claims (actionable on deliberate indifference), and it concludes the knowledge/acquiescence theory is available only where “the applicable constitutional standard is deliberate indifference.” A correct, narrower claim would say (i) for the deliberate-indifference failure-to-protect claim, Starr indicates a supervisor may be liable for his own culpable action/inaction and may be pleaded based on knowledge and acquiescence when deliberate indifference is the governing standard; but (ii) for the Equal Protection discrimination theory, Iqbal requires facts plausibly showing the supervisor acted with discriminatory purpose, so mere knowledge/condoning allegations are insufficient. Also fail if the memo flips the error the other way by claiming Iqbal categorically eliminated supervisory liability for deliberate-indifference jail-conditions claims, contrary to Starr’s limited holding.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the memo collapse the deliberate-indifference standard into the purposeful-discrimination standard, or vice versa.', 'Do not allow a categorical statement like “Iqbal abolished supervisory liability” without acknowledging Starr’s claim-specific distinction.', 'Do not credit broad statements that “knowledge and acquiescence always suffices” without the deliberate-indifference limitation.', 'Watch for the memo treating Starr’s reading as binding outside the deliberate-indifference conditions-of-confinement context described.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query: Draft a partner-ready memo section opposing the City’s Rule 12(b)(6) motion in our §1983 due process retaliation case. I need you to (1) lay out the governing pleading standard post-Twombly/Iqbal, and (2) argue there is no “heightened pleading” requirement for municipal-liability/civil-rights complaints and that plaintiffs are not required to expressly plead §1983 or plead Monell facts with particularity. Please support that with the key holdings and at least two verbatim quotations (with exact pincites) from Leatherman v. Tarrant County Narcotics Intelligence & Coordination Unit, 507 U.S. 163 (1993), Crawford-El v. Britton, 523 U.S. 574 (1998), and Johnson v. City of Shelby, 574 U.S. ___ (2014). Also add one Ninth Circuit case applying Leatherman to Monell pleading (quote and pincite).
scenario_facts: ['We represent four former city employees terminated after reporting alleged misconduct by a city official; they plead Fourteenth Amendment due process violations and seek damages from the City only (no individual defendants).', 'The City moved to dismiss, arguing the complaint is defective because it does not cite 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and does not plead a specific Monell policy/custom with detailed facts.', 'We have a short amendment window; the partner wants an opposition that squarely addresses whether omission of an express §1983 citation and lack of detailed Monell allegations are fatal at the pleading stage, using only the provided packet authorities.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC008.P001.B04', 'DOC008.P002.B03']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'This item is testing for fabricated authority and fake citations. The user asks for verbatim quotations, exact pincites, and additional cases (Leatherman, Crawford-El, and a Ninth Circuit Monell/Leatherman application) that are not actually provided in the packet text. A correct response must not invent quotes, holdings, docket numbers, or pinpoint citations for any authority that is not contained in the packet blocks. Any citation that does not match a real packet block ID (DOC###.P###.B##) should be treated as a failure, as should any paraphrased “quote” presented as a quotation from a non-provided case. It is acceptable (and should score well) to explain that the packet contains Johnson v. City of Shelby and pleading-standard material, but does not include the full text of Leatherman or Crawford-El (or any Ninth Circuit Monell/Leatherman case) and therefore the assistant cannot provide verbatim quotes or accurate pincites for those missing sources. The response may still use and cite packet language accurately and propose what additional research is needed, but it must clearly label any non-packet knowledge as unavailable here and refrain from guessing.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not fabricate direct quotations or page pincites to Leatherman or Crawford-El.', 'Do not cite any non-packet case as if it appears in the packet documents.', 'Do not create fake Ninth Circuit citations purporting to apply Leatherman to Monell pleading.', 'If only a case name is mentioned in the packet, do not treat that mention as providing the case’s holding or quotable language.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query: I need a partner-ready memo section for a 12(b)(6) motion in the Ninth Circuit: after Iqbal and Starr v. Baca, when (if ever) can a plaintiff plead § 1983 supervisory liability against a county sheriff based mainly on allegations the sheriff knew about prior jail violence/abuse and failed to act? Also address whether the same “knowledge and acquiescence” theory works for an Equal Protection race-discrimination claim against the sheriff in his individual capacity on these facts.
scenario_facts: ['Federal § 1983 suit in the Ninth Circuit arising out of a county jail incident.', 'Plaintiff is a pretrial detainee who alleges he was attacked by other inmates after deputies opened his cell door and failed to intervene promptly; plaintiff alleges serious injuries.', 'Complaint sues the sheriff in his individual capacity (not just official capacity) and does not allege the sheriff was present at the incident or personally directed the deputies that day.', 'As to the sheriff, the complaint alleges (a) the sheriff received DOJ findings letters / monitoring reports and internal reports describing patterns of inmate-on-inmate violence and deputy excessive force over many years, (b) the sheriff received weekly incident reports about injuries, and (c) despite this notice, the sheriff failed to implement adequate supervision/training/discipline to stop the pattern.', 'The complaint uses “knew or should have known” language and characterizes the sheriff as having ‘acquiesced’ in unconstitutional conduct by subordinates by failing to act.', 'Separately, the complaint pleads an Equal Protection claim alleging some deputies used racial slurs and targeted plaintiff because of race during/after the incident, but it does not plead facts showing the sheriff personally acted with discriminatory purpose; it alleges only that the sheriff knew about a general pattern of deputy misconduct and did not stop it.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC003.P008.B05', 'DOC003.P007.B03'], ['DOC003.P006.B04', 'DOC003.P007.B01'], ['DOC003.P009.B02', 'DOC003.P009.B03']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade the memo strictly on whether the cited propositions are actually supported by the cited packet blocks. If the memo states a rule (e.g., what a plaintiff must plead for supervisory liability, or what mental state is required) without citing any packet authority, treat that as unsupported even if it sounds legally familiar. If the memo cites a block that discusses a different constitutional theory or a different procedural posture, do not credit the citation unless the block clearly supports the proposition as used. Do not give partial credit for citations that are merely “about” Iqbal/Twombly generally; the citation must match the specific point asserted. If the memo introduces external doctrines or cases not in the packet, that should be treated as a fabrication for grading purposes. If the memo uses quotations, graders should verify the quoted words appear in the cited blocks. Any mismatch between the memo’s claim and the packet text should be treated as a citation integrity failure, not a harmless imprecision.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept citations that mention deliberate indifference as support for purposeful discrimination elements.', 'Do not accept a cite to general Rule 8 pleading language as support for Ninth Circuit supervisory-liability causation requirements.', 'If the memo cites Starr but claims it applies nationwide or to all constitutional claims, treat that as unsupported by the cited block.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo treats DOC003 (Starr) as establishing a blanket rule that “knowledge and acquiescence” (or “knew or should have known”) is sufficient to plead supervisory liability for any § 1983/Bivens claim, including Equal Protection purposeful race discrimination. That is legally wrong under the packet because Starr’s discussion is tied to claims where the applicable constitutional standard is deliberate indifference, and it distinguishes Iqbal’s requirement of discriminatory purpose for discrimination claims. A correct, narrower statement is that supervisory liability may be pleaded based on the supervisor’s own culpable action/inaction (including knowledge and acquiescence) when the underlying constitutional claim’s mental state is deliberate indifference, but discrimination claims require allegations that the supervisor himself acted with discriminatory purpose rather than mere awareness. Also fail if the memo implies Starr eliminates the need to plead a causal connection between the supervisor’s wrongful conduct and the specific constitutional violation; the packet describes supervisory liability as requiring personal involvement or a sufficient causal connection, which is not automatically satisfied by general “notice” allegations. Finally, fail if the memo converts permissive/conditional language (“may state a claim where deliberate indifference is the standard”) into an absolute (“must survive dismissal whenever prior incidents are alleged”) without the packet’s qualifiers.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not let the memo collapse deliberate-indifference supervisory liability into a universal rule for all constitutional torts.', 'Do not credit statements suggesting “should have known” negligence alone satisfies deliberate indifference under Starr’s supervisory-liability discussion.', 'Do not accept claims that a supervisor’s mere awareness of subordinates’ discriminatory acts suffices for Equal Protection discrimination claims.', 'Do not accept assertions that Starr dispenses with pleading or proving a causal connection between supervisor conduct and the plaintiff’s injury.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query:
Need a partner-ready memo on the Rule 12(b)(6) pleading standard for our motion to dismiss in a §1983 jail-conditions case in the Central District of California. Plaintiff’s opposition keeps quoting Conley’s “no set of facts” language and argues dismissal is basically impossible unless the court can rule out every conceivable set of facts. Can you assess the correct governing standard and how we should frame our argument in light of the Supreme Court cases and Ninth Circuit authority?

Facts: Plaintiff (pretrial detainee) sues the County Sheriff in his individual capacity, alleging supervisory liability for deliberate indifference to inmate-on-inmate violence. The complaint alleges the Sheriff “knew or should have known” the jail was dangerous based on prior incidents and reports, but it doesn’t allege the Sheriff was personally involved in the specific attack. Plaintiff argues notice pleading under Conley/Swierkiewicz is enough and wants discovery.
scenario_facts: ['Forum: U.S. District Court, Central District of California (Ninth Circuit). Motion at issue is a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss.', 'Claims: §1983 unconstitutional conditions of confinement / deliberate indifference theory against a supervisory official (the Sheriff) in his individual capacity (not an official-capacity/Monell claim).', 'Pleading: The complaint includes generalized allegations that the Sheriff “knew or should have known” about dangerous jail conditions from prior incidents and oversight reports, but does not allege the Sheriff was present for, directed, or personally participated in the plaintiff’s specific assault.', 'Opposition: Plaintiff’s brief relies heavily on Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation and argues dismissal is improper unless the court can say there is literally no possible set of facts consistent with the complaint that could entitle plaintiff to relief.', 'Desired memo focus: Identify which authorities control the pleading standard and how to treat older or non-controlling formulations when they conflict with later Supreme Court precedent.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC001.P019.B02', 'DOC001.P012.B04', 'DOC001.P002.B05'], ['DOC002.P003.B03', 'DOC002.P017.B06', 'DOC002.P018.B03']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade citation integrity strictly and at the proposition level. A response should only cite packet authorities for legal rules it actually attributes to those sources (e.g., what the Supreme Court requires at Rule 12(b)(6), what happens to Conley’s “no set of facts” language, and how to treat conclusory allegations). If the memo claims a case “overruled,” “abrogated,” or “limited” another case, it must be supported by the cited packet text reflecting that status; do not award credit for unsupported status assertions. If the memo adds extra holdings, procedural posture details, or jurisdictional nuances not shown in the cited blocks, treat that as a citation integrity problem even if the general idea sounds right. Do not accept citations that are merely adjacent to the relevant point; the cited block must actually contain the claimed rule. If the memo uses no citation or cites the wrong document for a key rule, treat the related legal assertion as unsupported. Minor miscites are acceptable only if the cited block still clearly supports the exact proposition stated.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit statements that Conley’s test remains governing unless the cited block says that.', 'Do not credit a memo that claims Twombly or Iqbal applies only to antitrust or only to Bivens without packet support.', 'Do not credit invented Ninth Circuit-specific pleading tweaks or heightened standards absent packet citations showing them.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': None, 'overextension_cautions': [], 'precedence_trigger_note': 'This item is about authority hierarchy and “still good law” handling. The controlling law on the Rule 12(b)(6) pleading standard in federal court is the later-in-time Supreme Court articulation in Twombly and Iqbal, including Twombly’s express retirement of Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation and Iqbal’s instruction that courts need not accept conclusory allegations as true. Fail the response if it treats Conley’s “no set of facts” language as the governing standard, uses it to define the dismissal test, or suggests that Twombly/Iqbal merely “criticized” Conley but left it intact. That mistake is legally wrong because later Supreme Court precedent displaces inconsistent earlier formulations for the same Federal Rule 8/12(b)(6) question, and Twombly explicitly says Conley’s quoted phrase is “best forgotten” as a pleading standard. To pass, the memo must (1) state that the plausibility framework controls and (2) explain why Conley’s “no set of facts” wording cannot be relied on as the operative standard after Twombly/Iqbal, while still allowing that older notice-pleading concepts survive only as consistent with the plausibility approach. The memo should also reflect Iqbal’s two-step approach (conclusory allegations not assumed true; then assess plausibility from well-pleaded facts) as part of correct authority handling.', 'precedence_cautions': ['Do not treat an older Supreme Court formulation as controlling when a later Supreme Court decision expressly retires or rejects it.', 'Do not present Conley’s “no set of facts” language as the Rule 12(b)(6) test after Twombly/Iqbal.', 'Do not dilute the hierarchy by claiming lower-court gloss can override Supreme Court pleading standards.', 'Do not ignore Iqbal’s direction to disregard conclusory allegations when assessing plausibility under Rule 8.']}

user_query: I need a quick partner-facing memo on whether we can keep the Sheriff in our §1983 complaint at the Rule 12(b)(6) stage on a supervisory-liability theory for alleged religious/national-origin discrimination by jail deputies. Opposing counsel is citing Iqbal to argue we have to plead the Sheriff’s own discriminatory purpose, not just that he knew what deputies were doing. Can we rely on Starr v. Baca to argue knowledge/acquiescence is enough, or does Iqbal bar that for discrimination claims?
scenario_facts: ['Case is in federal court within the Ninth Circuit; defendant has filed (or will file) a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss the individual-capacity claims against the Sheriff.', 'Plaintiff alleges line deputies routinely called Muslim detainees “terrorists,” interfered with prayer, and imposed harsher housing restrictions on Arab/Muslim detainees than similarly situated non-Muslim detainees.', 'The complaint does not allege the Sheriff personally spoke to plaintiff or personally made classification decisions about plaintiff; it alleges (i) multiple prior grievances and lawsuits put the Sheriff on notice that deputies were targeting Muslim detainees, (ii) the Sheriff received regular reports about jail incidents and civil claims, and (iii) he failed to discipline, retrain, or change practices, thereby “condoning” the discrimination.', 'Claims against the Sheriff are pleaded as supervisory liability in his individual capacity; plaintiff is not relying on respondeat superior.', 'Plaintiff is asserting purposeful discrimination-type claims (e.g., Equal Protection / Free Exercise style allegations), not an Eighth/Fourteenth conditions-of-confinement deliberate-indifference claim.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC002.P015.B05', 'DOC002.P016.B02', 'DOC002.P016.B04'], ['DOC003.P007.B03', 'DOC003.P007.B04', 'DOC003.P008.B05']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade the answer on whether it ties each key legal proposition to the specific cited language in the packet, not on whether the proposition sounds generally correct. If the memo claims that “Starr holds knowledge and acquiescence is enough for supervisory liability in any §1983 case,” the grader should check whether the cited Starr passage actually says that, and mark it as unsupported if it omits Starr’s deliberate-indifference limitation. If the memo states that Iqbal requires a supervisor’s own discriminatory purpose for discrimination claims, it must cite the packet language on purposeful discrimination and no vicarious liability. Do not give credit for citations that are merely about pleading generally unless they support the specific point asserted. Any citation to non-packet authorities, or invented pincites/quotes, should be treated as a citation-integrity failure. If the memo uses a packet citation token but attributes to it a rule that is not in that block, treat that as unsupported just like a fabricated citation.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not credit citations that address Rule 8 generally as support for the discrimination-intent element requirement.', 'Do not credit citations to Starr’s factual recitation as if it were a general rule about discrimination claims.', 'Do not credit any claim about “all circuits” or nationwide rules unless supported by the packet text.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo states, in categorical or near-categorical terms, that a supervisor’s “knowledge and acquiescence” (or notice plus failure to act) is sufficient to plead individual supervisory liability for purposeful discrimination claims after Iqbal. That is legally wrong on this packet because Iqbal requires each official’s own misconduct and explains that purposeful discrimination requires action taken “because of” the adverse effects, not merely awareness, so a supervisor’s mere knowledge of subordinates’ discriminatory purpose is not enough. Starr does not authorize a blanket knowledge/acquiescence theory across all constitutional torts; it expressly distinguishes discrimination claims (which require purposeful discrimination) from conditions-of-confinement claims (which are actionable on deliberate indifference) and only then says a plaintiff may state supervisory liability based on knowledge and acquiescence where deliberate indifference is the applicable constitutional standard. A correct, narrower statement would say: for discrimination claims, plead facts plausibly showing the Sheriff himself acted with discriminatory purpose; Starr’s knowledge/acquiescence formulation is tied to deliberate-indifference contexts (e.g., conditions of confinement), not to purposeful discrimination. The memo may still argue about plausibility and what facts might support purpose, but it must not treat Starr as eliminating Iqbal’s intent requirement for discrimination. Also fail if the memo implies Starr “overruled” or “limited” Iqbal on discrimination intent; the packet does not support that.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Avoid turning Starr’s “where the applicable constitutional standard is deliberate indifference” language into a universal supervisory-liability rule.', 'Avoid saying Iqbal eliminated supervisory liability entirely; Starr discusses that argument and rejects it only in deliberate-indifference contexts.', 'Avoid equating ‘intent may be alleged generally’ with ‘conclusory allegations are sufficient’; Iqbal rejects that move under Rule 8.', 'Avoid claiming that alleging notice via grievances/reports automatically establishes the supervisor’s own discriminatory purpose.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}

user_query: Need a quick partner memo for a Rule 12(b)(6) motion: in the Ninth Circuit, can we knock out an individual-capacity § 1983 claim against the county sheriff based on “supervisory liability” after Iqbal? Plaintiff is a pretrial detainee who says deputies opened his cell door to let other inmates assault him, and he’s suing the sheriff for (1) deliberate indifference to unsafe jail conditions and (2) Equal Protection discrimination. Can we argue that allegations the sheriff “knew or should have known” about prior similar incidents are legally insufficient at the pleading stage, and that Iqbal requires more than knowledge/acquiescence?
scenario_facts: ['Federal case in the Ninth Circuit; defendants include the County, several line deputies, and the elected County Sheriff in his individual capacity.', 'Plaintiff (a pretrial detainee) alleges that, during lockdown, a deputy intentionally opened his cell door so other inmates could enter and beat him; plaintiff alleges he yelled for help and deputies did not intervene promptly.', 'Complaint asserts two theories against the Sheriff personally: (a) Fourteenth Amendment conditions-of-confinement / failure-to-protect based on deliberate indifference; and (b) Equal Protection purposeful discrimination, alleging plaintiff was targeted for violence because of race.', 'As to the Sheriff, the complaint pleads generally that the Sheriff “knew or should have known” of a pattern of deputy facilitation of inmate-on-inmate assaults and excessive force in the jail, and that the Sheriff “failed to act,” “condoned,” or “ratified” the pattern.', 'For factual support, the complaint cites: one DOJ findings letter from years earlier about unconstitutional jail conditions, two prior civil lawsuits alleging deputy misconduct (settled without admissions), and a local newspaper article describing violence in the jail.', 'The complaint does not allege the Sheriff was present for plaintiff’s assault or personally directed the deputy to open the cell door, and it alleges no explicit written policy ordering deputies to facilitate assaults.', 'We are preparing an early motion to dismiss the claims against the Sheriff individually; we are not addressing Monell liability against the County in this memo.']
grading_contract: {'expected_citation_groups': [['DOC003.P008.B05', 'DOC003.P025.B01'], ['DOC002.P016.B04', 'DOC002.P016.B02'], ['DOC003.P009.B02']], 'citation_integrity_trigger_note': 'Grade the memo strictly on whether the cited propositions are actually supported by the cited packet text. If the memo asserts a rule, limitation, or holding about supervisory liability, deliberate indifference, or Equal Protection intent, it must be backed by at least one of the required citation tokens. Do not give credit for citations that discuss a different claim type (e.g., antitrust pleading) unless the memo clearly ties the point to the cited language. Treat pinpoint citations as commitments: if the cited block does not reasonably support the proposition as written, that is a citation integrity failure. If the memo adds extra “black letter” tests (e.g., elements, burdens, or categorical bars) not grounded in the packet, that should be marked as unsupported even if generally true elsewhere. If the memo cites no packet authority for a key proposition, or relies on invented case names/quotes, that should be treated as fabrication. The grader should not infer support from general familiarity with the cases; only what is in the packet counts.', 'citation_integrity_cautions': ['Do not accept generic references to “Iqbal says” unless the cited block contains that specific point.', 'Reject citations used for propositions about Monell or municipal policy unless the cited text actually addresses them.', 'If the memo quotes language like “knowledge is enough” or “Iqbal eliminated supervisory liability,” verify those exact ideas appear in the cited blocks.'], 'overextension_trigger_note': 'Fail for overextension if the memo states, in substance, that “knowledge and acquiescence is sufficient for supervisory liability in any § 1983 case” or that “Starr v. Baca held Iqbal does not affect supervisory liability generally,” without limiting the statement to contexts where the underlying constitutional violation uses a deliberate-indifference standard. That overclaim is legally wrong on this packet because Starr’s permissive statement is expressly tied to deliberate indifference as the applicable constitutional standard, and the packet’s Iqbal discussion makes clear that for unconstitutional discrimination, purpose rather than mere knowledge is required. Also fail if the memo uses Starr’s deliberate-indifference discussion to conclude that a supervisor can be liable for Equal Protection discrimination based solely on awareness or acquiescence, without alleging the supervisor’s own discriminatory purpose. A correct, packet-faithful framing is narrower: (1) supervisory liability can exist where the claim’s state-of-mind requirement is deliberate indifference and the supervisor’s own culpable action/inaction (including knowledge and acquiescence) is plausibly alleged; (2) for discrimination claims, the supervisor must be alleged to have acted with discriminatory purpose, not merely to have known of subordinates’ intent; and (3) in either event, the plaintiff must plausibly allege personal involvement or a sufficient causal connection, not just a title-based theory.', 'overextension_cautions': ['Do not turn Starr’s deliberate-indifference holding into a universal rule for all constitutional torts.', 'Do not say Iqbal “abolished supervisory liability” or “approved knowledge-and-acquiescence liability” across the board; the packet is more nuanced.', 'Avoid converting permissive language about what a plaintiff “may” allege into a mandatory or automatic liability rule.', 'Do not treat allegations of generalized “should have known” awareness as automatically sufficient; the packet requires a causal-connection/personal-involvement theory.'], 'precedence_trigger_note': None, 'precedence_cautions': []}
